qas.question: Who do Christians believe is prophesized in Isaiah 7:14?
What is the meaning of the Greek word "heos?"
Which verse in Matthew is believed to refer to Isaiah's prohecy of the Virgin Mary?
Which Gospel writer provided a version of the virgin birth that was different than Matthew's?
What is the English tranlation of the Greek word "parthenos?"
Who knew Mary before she brought forth her first born son?
Where did Philip first meet Joseph?
Where did Matthew and Luke gather with the disbelieving Jews?
What Biblical scholar currently believes that Mary was a perpetual virgin?
What language does Biblical scholar Bart Ehrmam primarily speak?

context: The statement that <b5_0>Joseph<b5_0/> "knew her not till she brought forth her first born son" (Matthew 1:25 DouayRheims) has been debated among scholars, with some saying that she did not remain a virgin and some saying that she was a perpetual virgin. Other scholars contend that the Greek word heos (i.e., <a1_0>until<a1_0/>) denotes a state up to a point, but does not mean that the state ended after that point, and that Matthew 1:25 does not confirm or deny the virginity of Mary after the birth of Jesus. According to Biblical scholar <b8_0>Bart Ehrman<b8_0/> the <b9_0>Hebrew<b9_0/> word almah, meaning young woman of childbearing age, was translated into Greek as parthenos, which only means <a4_0>virgin<a4_0/>, in Isaiah 7:14, which is commonly believed by Christians to be the prophecy of the <a0_0>Virgin Mary<a0_0/> referred to in Matthew <a2_0>1:23<a2_0/>. While Matthew and <a3_0>Luke<a3_0/> give differing versions of the virgin birth, John quotes the uninitiated Philip and the disbelieving Jews gathered at <b6_0><b7_0>Galilee<b7_0/><b6_0/> referring to Joseph as Jesus's father.
